Class Table is the main hub for this black jack application.
Connects decks and participants. Receives and forwards events from deck and participants. Dictates the gameplay.

member.name: M:BlackJack.Table.ContinueGame
member.summary:
Method which takes the first active hand and triggers/asks for an action on that hand.
If there are no more active hands or players; - calculate the winning/result - remove inactive players - clear the m_handRecord dictionary

member.summary: Method to handle a player action on a specific handId. After action and handId have been verified OK, action is performed and event is sent to inform about the new hands.

member.name: T:BlackJack.ListManager.Utils
member.summary:
Method to return random number.
This single static random generator is there because if we are going to create more than one random number, we need to keep the Random instance and reuse it. If we create new instances too close in time, they will produce the same series of random numbers as the random generator is seeded from the system clock.

member.summary: Method to shuffle a list.

member.summary: Method which tries to access element index in list-string-. If element is present at index, then that element (type: string) is returned. If element is not present at index, then N/A string is returned.

member.name: M:BlackJack.XMLSerializerUtility.Serialize``1(``0,System.String)
member.summary: Method to write the given object to an XML file - Only writes and reads the Public properties and variables to / from the file. - Classes to be serialized must contain a public parameterless constructor. - The data saved to the file is human readable, so it can easily be edited outside of your application. - Use the [XmlIgnore] attribute to exclude a public property or variable from being written to the file.

member.name: M:BlackJack.XMLSerializerUtility.DeSerialize``1(System.String)
member.summary: Method to read an object instance of a XML file. - Only writes and reads the Public properties and variables to / from the file. - Classes to be serialized must contain a public parameterless constructor. - The data saved to the file is human readable, so it can easily be edited outside of your application. - Use the [XmlIgnore] attribute to exclude a public property or variable from being written to the file.
